data.name: Functional programming in JS/TS -  Part 2: Projecting Arrays with map()
data.description:
The precedent kata illustrates that all array projections share two operations in common:
 1. Traverse the source array
 1. Add each item's projected value to a new array

Why not abstract away *how* these operations are carried out? 

To make projections easier, this kata will look at defining our own `map()` function, `myMap()`. `myMap()` accepts the projection funtion to be applied to each item in the source array, and returns the projected array. Use this function to replace the `forEach()`-based implementation in Part 1, by projecting the videos array into an array of `{id, title}` pairs using the `newMap()` function.

Use your implementation to refactor the precedent kata, that is a function `getIndexedReleases()` which uses `myMap()` instead of `forEach()`.

Notice that `map()` allows us to specify *what* projection we want to apply to an array, but hides *how* the operation is carried out.

## Note: Attribution
This kata is part of a series on functional programming in JS/TS. This series is an adaptation of the *Functional Programming in Javascript* online exercises: http://reactivex.io/learnrx/ (Apache 2 license).
